cs.CR, cs.SE, cs.PL, cs.AR, cs.SY. 

The paper deals with security vulnerabilities in software, specifically double-fetch bugs, and proposes techniques to detect, exploit, and eliminate them. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the cs.CR (Cryptography and Security) sub-category. Additionally, the paper discusses the use of modern CPU features such as hardware transactional memory, which could also place it in the cs.AR (Architecture) sub-category. The paper also mentions the use of fuzzing techniques, which could place it in the cs.SE (Software Engineering) sub-category. The paper proposes modifications to code to prevent double-fetch bugs, which could place it in the cs.PL (Programming Languages) sub-category. Finally, the paper discusses the use of these techniques in kernel and syscall environments, which could place it in the cs.SY (Systems and Control) sub-category.
